Graphical abstract The design of highly enantioselective heterogeneous catalysts offers an efficient route for the production of enantiopure chiral molecules, which are crucial intermediates in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and fine chemical industries. In this study, we present a strategy to enhance the enantioselectivity of supported Pt catalysts for the hydrogenation of α-keto esters by modifying SiO2 supports with poly(ethyleneimine) (PEI), a nitrogen-rich polymer. By adjusting the heat-treatment time, the quantity of PEI-derived residues on the support was successfully controlled, thereby fine-tuning the electronic state of Pt through electron-transfer interactions, and resulting in the generation of positively charged Pt species. Catalytic evaluations showed that the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts exhibited superior enantioselectivities compared to the unmodified Pt/SiO2, with an optimal performance of 96.1% enantiomeric excess (ee). In addition, the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts exhibited high enantioselectivities using various α-keto esters, chiral modifiers, and H2 pressures, as well as an excellent reusability over ten consecutive cycles. The observed correlation between the higher proportion of positively charged Pt species and the increased ee suggests that the improved enantioselectivity of the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalyst system is driven by the enhanced adsorption of chiral modifiers, which is facilitated by interactions between the anchoring moiety and the electron-deficient Pt surface. These findings highlight the essential role of interactions between the active metals and the modifying organic species bound to support materials in enhancing the enantioselectivity. Moreover, they provide valuable insights for catalyst design through electronic tuning of the active metal surface with organic-modified supports. Keywords Enantioselective hydrogenation α-keto ester Supported Pt catalyst Modified SiO2 support Poly(ethyleneimine) Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of highly selective catalysts is crucial in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, particularly for applications in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and fine chemical industries, where precise control over the product distribution is essential [1–4]. A promising strategy for modulating the selectivity of active metal nanoparticles (NPs) involves modifying the support materials with organic molecules [5–13]. Such organic modifications can significantly influence the interactions between the support and the active metal NPs, thereby altering the electronic and chemical states of the NPs [9,14]. Additionally, strong interactions of the functional groups of organic molecules with the NPs can improve the overall NP dispersion and stability [8,9,15]. Furthermore, the wide availability of organic molecules with varying chain lengths, steric constraints, and functional groups, further allows tailoring of the surface environment surrounding the active NPs [9–11]. Consequently, organic-modified supports provide a unique platform for optimizing catalytic performances, opening new opportunities to enhance selectivities in targeted reactions. An important consideration in the design of organic-modified supports is achieving a delicate balance between the amount of organic modifier interacting with the active metal NPs and sufficient exposure of the NP surface to promote the catalytic reaction [11,16,17]. More specifically, despite the improved selectivities achieved using such organic modifiers, excessive blockage of the NP active sites can prevent reactant molecules from accessing the catalytic sites, significantly reducing the activity of the catalyst [16,18–21]. Conversely, insufficient organic modification may fail to provide the desired electronic or stabilization effects. Thus, to achieve the desired balance and optimize both the catalyst selectivity and the activity, heat treatment of the modified supports under mild conditions has been demonstrated as an effective approach [12,16]. Although some partial decomposition and removal of the organic molecules occurs, this heat-treatment process leaves thermally stabilized organic residues on the support materials, ensuring sufficient exposure of the active sites, while retaining the beneficial electronic and structural properties imparted by the organic residues [16–21]. The enantioselective hydrogenation of α-keto esters is a delicate but essential reaction for the production of enantiopure chiral alcohols, which are crucial intermediates in various pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals (Scheme 1 ) [22,23]. To achieve high enantioselectivities using heterogeneous catalysts, such as supported Pt catalysts, it is necessary to impart chirality to the metal surface. This is typically achieved by introducing chiral modifiers, such as cinchona alkaloids [24–28]. The chiral modifiers adsorbed on the Pt surface interact with the α-keto esters, forming enantiodifferentiating surface complexes that drive the enantioselective hydrogenation process [28–31]. Thus, facilitating the adsorption of chiral modifier molecules onto the metal surface is a key strategy for improving the enantioselectivities of supported Pt catalysts. Notably, the interactions between cinchona alkaloids and Pt NPs are highly dependent on the electronic state of Pt, with electron-deficient Pt species promoting the effective adsorption of chiral modifiers via quinoline [29,32,33]. Thus, we herein report a strategy for modulating of the electronic properties of Pt NPs by modifying a SiO2 support with poly(ethyleneimine) (PEI), a nitrogen-rich polymer that readily forms layers on the support surface [34–36]. To optimize the accessibility of the bare (active) Pt surface for the adsorption of both reactants and chiral modifiers, while also harnessing the beneficial properties imparted by the organic molecules, the PEI-modified SiO2 support is thermally treated under mild conditions with variations in the heat-treatment time. The catalytic performance and reusability of the supported Pt catalysts are subsequently evaluated in the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-keto esters. In addition, the promoting effect of the PEI-modified SiO2 support is compared with that of an unmodified SiO2 support using various reactants, chiral modifiers, and H2 pressures. Furthermore, the correlation between the enantioselectivity of the supported Pt catalyst and the chemical state of the Pt NPs is investigated, revealing the role of the PEI-modified SiO2 support. These findings offer insights into enhancing catalytic performance through organic-inorganic interactions by modulating the electronic states of active metal NPs using organic-modified supports. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials The PEI-modified SiO2 supports were prepared using fumed SiO2 powder (specific surface area = 419 m2/g, Sigma-Aldrich) and PEI (branched, molecular weight = ∼800, Sigma-Aldrich). Platinum (II) acetylacetonate (Pt(acac)2, 98%, Acros) was used as the Pt precursor for preparing Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts. For the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-keto esters, the following substrates were used as reactants: methyl pyruvate (MP, >97%, TCI), ethyl pyruvate (EP, 98%, TCI), methyl benzoylformate (MBF, 99%, Acros) and ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate (EOPB, 97%, Sigma-Aldrich). Cinchona alkaloids such as cinchonidine (CD; 96%, Sigma-Aldrich), cinchonine (CN; 98%, Alfa Aesar), quinidine (QD; 98%, Alfa Aesar), and quinine (QN; >98%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as chiral modifiers. Acetic acid (AcOH, 99.7%, Samchun Pure Chemical) and n-tetradecane (>99%, Alfa Aesar) were used as the solvent and internal standard, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The PEI-modified SiO2 supports were prepared as follows: 1 g of fumed SiO2 was dispersed in 6 mL of deionized water, and then, a solution containing 2 g of PEI in 2 mL of deionized water was added. After stirring at 298 K for 1 h, the solution was dried at 373 K for 12 h and the dried powder was then calcined in a furnace at 623 K for t = 1–5 h (t indicates calcination time) in air to vary the amount of PEI on the SiO2 surface. The calcined supports were designated PEI-SiO2-t. Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts were synthesized by impregnating the prepared PEI-SiO2-t supports with a Pt precursor. The PEI-SiO2-t supports were suspended in an acetone solution of 1 wt.% Pt(acac)2, and the solvent was removed by evaporation at 313 K with stirring. The resultant powder was dried at 353 K for 12 h and heat-treated under Ar at 623 K for 3 h. As a reference catalyst, Pt/SiO2 was prepared using the same method but with a SiO2 support without PEI modification. 2.3 Characterization To measure the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area (S BET), N2 physisorption was performed at 77 K after the pretreatment of the sample at 473 K for 12 h in vacuum. To confirm the presence of organic species on Pt/PEI-SiO2-t, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was performed using the sample pelleted with KBr. FTIR transmittance spectra were obtained from 400 to 4000 cm−1 with 128 scans at a spectral resolution of 4 cm−1 at 298 K. The Pt content of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using Cu Kα radiation generated at 40 kV and 20 mA. A transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was carried out to measure the Pt particle size (d TEM) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV at the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI), Gwangju, South Korea. Derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) curves were obtained using a HITACHI STA 7300 analyzer between 373 and 1073 K under air flow. The nitrogen and carbon content in the PEI-SiO2-t supports and Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts was quantified using a Vario MICRO cube instrument. CO pulse chemisorption on the Pt surface of Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts was carried out at 323 K. Prior to measurement, the sample was pretreated with a stream of H2 at 473 K for 2 h. The amount of bare Pt sites on the surface of the Pt NPs available for catalysis (Ptsurface), i.e., surface Pt sites not covered by PEI residues, and Pt particle size (d CO) were quantified by measuring the moles of CO adsorbed on the exposed Pt surface sites (COads) and assuming a COads/Ptsurface adsorption stoichiometry of 1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) at the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI), Busan, South Korea. The C 1s peak at 284.6 eV was used as the reference for all binding energies. 2.4 Catalytic performance tests Prior to the catalytic tests, the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts were pre-reduced at 473 K in a 5% H2/Ar flow for 2 h. The catalytic tests were carried out at 298 K in a 250 mL three-way flask at an H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa and in an autoclave with a 100 mL glass liner at an H2 pressure of 0.5–5.0 MPa. First, the pre-reduced Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts (30 mg) were dispersed in AcOH (5 mL). A solution of chiral modifier (0.7 × 10–2 mmol) in AcOH (3 mL) was then injected into the reactor under stirring. After purging the reactor with H2 for 15 min at 298 K, the reaction was initiated by adding a solution of α-keto ester (0.55 mmol) and internal standard (0.1 mL) in AcOH (2 mL) under stirring. At the end of the reaction, the spent catalyst powder was separated using a syringe filter. Aliquots of the resulting solution were taken and analyzed on a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and chiral capillary column (Chirasil-Dex CB, CP7502, Agilent). Initial turnover frequencies (TOFs) were determined using equation (1) at a conversion level of 8–15%. (1) TOF h - 1 = N × x × V CO ads × s × W × t Here, N, x, V, COads , s, W, and t represent the number of moles of α-keto esters, measured conversion of the reactants, volume per mole at standard conditions (22414 cm3·mol−1), volume of CO adsorbed on the Pt surface (measured by chemisorption), adsorption stoichiometry of CO/Pt (= 1), weight of the catalyst sample, and reaction time, respectively. The enantiomeric excess (ee) value was calculated using equation (2). (2) e e % = R - [ S ] R + [ S ] × 100 % Here, [R] and [S] represent the concentrations of the (R)- and (S)-alcohols, respectively, which are the hydrogenation products of α-keto esters. The standard deviations of TOF and ee were determined based on three or more replicate runs. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts A series of PEI-modified SiO2 supports, PEI-SiO2-t, was prepared by controlling the heat-treatment time, t = 1–5 h, at 623 K under an air atmosphere. Gentle heat-treatment resulted in the partial decomposition and removal of PEI from the SiO2 surface, leaving organic residues. For preparation of the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts, 1 wt.% Pt was deposited on the unmodified SiO2 and PEI-SiO2-t supports, respectively. As outlined in Table 1 , all supported Pt catalysts contained similar Pt contents of 1.1–1.3 wt.%. Although the N2 physisorption results for the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts showed similar adsorption/desorption isotherms, different S BET were obtained (Table 1 and Fig. S1). More specifically, it was found that all modified Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts possessed lower surface areas (S BET = 216–276 m2/g) than the unmodified Pt/SiO2 catalyst (S BET = 375 m2/g), indicating successful modification of the SiO2 support by PEI, and confirming the presence of organic residues on the SiO2 surfaces. A comparison of the S BET values between the different Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts showed that a longer heat-treatment time led to a higher S BET value, due to the gradual decomposition and elimination of PEI from the SiO2 surface. The TEM images for the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts confirm that the Pt particles are well-dispersed on the supports, with similar average NPs sizes of 1.6–1.7 nm (Fig. 1 ). In addition, the observation of no peaks corresponding to Pt crystallites in XRD patterns of the prepared catalysts also indicates the presence of highly dispersed and non-aggregated Pt particles on both the unmodified SiO2 and PEI-SiO2-t supports (Fig. S2). These observations suggest that the PEI-derived species present on the SiO2 support has no appreciable effect on the Pt particle size. Moreover, the EDS mapping images of a representative Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalyst showed that C and N were uniformly distributed on the SiO2 support, thereby confirming the uniform distribution of the PEI-derived species (Fig. S3). Heat treatment of pristine PEI on SiO2 in air led to the thermal decomposition of PEI starting around 473 K, suggesting the formation of thermally decomposed PEI residues during preparation of Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts (Fig. S4). The contents of the PEI-derived C and N atoms in the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts were quantitatively measured using elemental analysis (Table 2 ). The presence of PEI residues was confirmed by the measurable amounts of C and N compared to the negligible amounts detected for Pt/SiO2. The as-prepared Pt/PEI-SiO2 initially contained 30.7 wt.% C and 15.1 wt.% N. Upon heat treatment and extended treatment time, the C and N contents decreased due to the decomposition and partial removal of PEI. However, Pt/PEI-SiO2-5, which had been subjected to the longest heat-treatment time, still contained 3.3 wt.% C and 1.4 wt.% N, confirming that PEI residues were retained on all Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts. The presence of PEI residues was also confirmed by comparing the FTIR transmittance spectra of the unmodified Pt/SiO2 and modified Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts (Fig. 2 ). All catalysts exhibited a strong absorption band at 1633 cm−1, corresponding to the hydroxyl groups on the SiO2 surface [37–40]. In the full FTIR transmittance spectra, additional peaks associated with the SiO2 surface were observed, including bands at 3100–3700 cm−1 (surface or adsorbed OH), 1633 cm−1 (Si–OH), 1105 cm−1 (Si–O–Si asymmetric stretch), and 810 and 473 cm−1 (symmetric stretch and bending modes of Si–O–Si, respectively) (Fig. S5) [39–41]. Compared to Pt/SiO2, Pt/PEI-SiO2-t showed additional peaks at 2935, 2850, and 1385 cm−1, corresponding to the CH2 bending vibrations originating from PEI (Fig. S6) [42–44]. These peaks became weaker with longer heat-treatment times owing to the partial removal of the organic residues, leaving only a faint peak at 1385 cm−1 for the Pt/PEI-SiO2-5 catalyst. These observations are consistent with the results of the C and N elemental analyses. DTG analysis of PEI-SiO2-t samples indicated that the PEI residues formed after heat treatment likely differ in nature from pristine PEI, exhibiting higher thermal stability. This is evidenced by the weight loss observed in the DTG profiles at significantly higher temperatures (673–973 K) compared to that of pristine PEI (473–573 K) (Fig. S4). Despite difficulty in specifying the exact nature of the PEI residues on Pt/PEI-SiO2-t due to the complexity of thermally decomposed products, XPS analysis was conducted on as-prepared PEI-SiO2 and heat-treated Pt/PEI-SiO2-t samples to obtain relevant information (Fig. S7). As-prepared PEI-SiO2 exhibited a peak at 398.1 eV in the N 1 s region, attributed to the N atoms of pristine PEI. In contrast, Pt/PEI-SiO2-t exhibited a noticeably broader peak at higher binding energies (∼399.0 eV) compared to as-prepared PEI-SiO2, with additional components emerging. This broad peak can be deconvoluted into three distinct nitrogen species: pyridinic N (398.2 eV), pyrrolic N (399.8 eV), and graphitic N (401.3 eV) (Table S1) [45,46]. These species are likely attributed to the thermal decomposition of pristine PEI, followed by partial cyclization and dehydrogenation of the resulting residues, predominantly forming pyridinic N and pyrrolic N, along with a moderate amount of graphitic N. The organic species present on support materials often cover the surfaces of the active NPs and inhibit the adsorption of reactant molecules. Therefore, the number of bare Pt sites on the surface of the Pt NPs for catalysis (Ptsurface), i.e., the surface Pt sites not covered by organic residues, was quantified by measuring the number of moles of CO adsorbed on the exposed Pt surface sites (COads), assuming a COads/Ptsurface adsorption stoichiometry of 1:1. Consequently, the unmodified Pt/SiO2 gave a Ptsurface/Pttotal ratio of 0.43, with d CO = 2.0 nm, wherein d CO reflects the Pt NPs size estimated by CO chemisorption (Table 1). Notably, the d CO value was similar to the Pt NPs size measured by TEM imaging (d TEM), i.e., 1.6 nm. In contrast, the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts with similar Pt contents and d TEM values to those of Pt/SiO2 exhibited significantly lower Ptsurface/Pttotal ratios of 0.08–0.21. These results suggest that CO chemisorption on the Pt surface sites of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts was prevented by partial surface blocking by the PEI residues, resulting in an underestimation of the Ptsurface and therefore, a significant overestimation of d CO compared to d TEM. Moreover, it was found that the Ptsurface/Pttotal ratios of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts increased with an increasing heat-treatment time because of the reduced amount of PEI, as observed by FTIR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Interaction between the PEI residues and the Pt NPs not only affects the number of bare Pt sites available for the catalysis, but it also influences the electronic properties of the Pt NPs. To investigate this further, XPS was performed for the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t and unmodified Pt/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 3 ). Prior to XPS analysis, all catalysts were pre-reduced with H2 under the same pretreatment conditions used prior to the performance tests. As outlined in Table 3 , the unmodified Pt/SiO2 showed a Pt 4f7/2 peak with a binding energy of 71.3 eV, while the corresponding peaks for the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts shifted by 0.4–1.0 eV to slightly higher binding energies. This indicates that the strong interactions between the organic residues and the Pt NPs reduced the electron density on the Pt surface [32,47]. As mentioned above, the XPS spectra of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts in the N 1 s region indicated the predominant formation of PEI-derived residues with binding energies corresponding to pyrrolic and pyridinic N (Fig. S7). These observations suggest that both pyrrolic and pyridinic N species withdraw electrons from Pt, leading to a positive shift in the Pt 4f binding energy, consistent with the electron density change of Pt on N-doped carbon supports [47–49]. Specifically, Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts treated for 1–3 h exhibited higher binding energies (72.1–72.3 eV), whereas those treated for 4–5 h showed reduced binding energies (71.7–71.9 eV) due to the removal of PEI residues. To further investigate the change in the chemical state of Pt due to its interaction with the PEI residues, the Pt 4f spectra were deconvoluted into metallic Pt species, i.e., Pt0, and positively charged Pt species, i.e., Pt2+ and Pt x + (2 < x < 4). As presented in Table 3, the unmodified Pt/SiO2 showed comparable amounts of Pt0 and Pt2+ species, resulting in a 0.9 ratio of positively charged Pt species to metallic Pt0 species (i.e., (Pt2++Pt x +)/Pt0). However, the strong interactions between the PEI residues and the Pt NPs in the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts resulted in the presence of not only Pt0 and Pt2+ species, but also more positively charged Pt x + (2 < x < 4) species. Consequently, the (Pt2++Pt x +)/Pt0 ratio increased to 2.8 for Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 and then gradually decreased to 1.6 for Pt/PEI-SiO2-5. This result confirms that the electronic states of the Pt NPs were tuned by the PEI content, which was in turn controlled by the heat-treatment time. 3.2 Catalytic performances of the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts in the enantioselective MP hydrogenation The performances of the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts were subsequently compared in the enantioselective MP hydrogenation at 0.1 MPa H2 (Scheme 1). CD was used as a chiral modifier to impart enantioselectivity to the Pt surface. The conversion of MP and the ee of the product were measured as a function of the reaction time, and the results are presented in Fig. 4 . All catalysts demonstrated almost linear increases in conversion during the initial phase of the reaction, reaching full conversion within 30 min. More specifically, Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 achieved 100% conversion after 15 min, whereas Pt/SiO2 achieved full conversion after 30 min, thereby confirming the improved activity of Pt/PEI-SiO2-3. The use of CD as a chiral modifier resulted in the formation of (R)-methyl lactate as the main product, and after the early determination of the reaction enantioselectivity, no further reduction in the ee was observed for the remainder of the reaction. Interestingly, upon reaching full conversion, all Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts led to higher ee values than the unmodified Pt/SiO2, demonstrating the positive effect imparted by the residual PEI on the SiO2 support. The activities and enantioselectivities of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts were further investigated without and with chiral modifiers (Table 4 ). More specifically, without CD, the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts showed similar initial conversions of ∼10% after 20 min of reaction compared to the Pt/SiO2 catalyst, despite the lower number of available bare Pt sites on their NPs surfaces. Consequently, the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts gave higher TOFs, which were determined from the number of available surface Pt sites. In the absence of CD, no enantioselectivity was observed for any of the catalysts, confirming the critical role of the chiral modifier in the generation of chiral active sites upon adsorption on the Pt surface. With the use of CD, all Pt catalysts achieved initial conversions similar to those obtained in the absence of CD after only 2 min of reaction, with a 10-fold increase in TOF. This result is consistent with previous observations of rate acceleration by chiral modifiers in this catalytic system [37,50]. The enantioselectivity gradually increased when the PEI-modified SiO2 support was incorporated, and with increases in the heat-treatment time up to 3 h, giving ee values of 78.7, 84.9, 88.5, and 90.9% for the Pt/SiO2, Pt/PEI-SiO2-1, Pt/PEI-SiO2-2, and Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalysts, respectively. However, upon further increasing the heat-treatment time beyond 3 h, the enantioselectivity decreased, giving ee values of 86.1 and 84.9% for the Pt/PEI-SiO2-4 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-5 catalysts, respectively. Notably, despite containing the lowest amount of residual PEI among the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts, Pt/PEI-SiO2-5 exhibited a higher enantioselectivity than unmodified Pt/SiO2. This trend confirms not only the beneficial effect of PEI residues, but also the importance of controlling their amount on the Pt catalyst surface. In the heterogeneous enantioselective hydrogenation over cinchona alkaloid-modified Pt catalysts, the adsorption of the chiral modifier onto the Pt surface is a prerequisite for the induction of enantioselectivity, as it forms an enantiodifferentiating surface complex with the substrate [51,52]. Previous studies have shown that the electron-deficient nature of Pt NPs enhances the adsorption of quinoline [29,33]. Thus, considering that the quinoline moieties of cinchona alkaloids anchor onto the Pt surfaces, this observation suggests that positively charged Pt species can contribute to improving the enantioselectivities of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts [29,32]. Therefore, the change in the proportion of positively charged Pt species (Pt2+ and Pt x +), p (%), of the supported Pt catalysts, estimated by XPS, was compared with the change in ee values. As presented in Fig. 5 , the increased enantioselectivity observed for the Pt/PEI-SiO2-t catalysts correlated with the proportion of positively charged Pt species. These results confirm that the presence of PEI residues, which strongly interact with the Pt NPs, can facilitate the adsorption of CD on the Pt surface by generating positively charged Pt species, with Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 achieving the highest ee of 90.9%. However, in addition to this beneficial effect, excess or longer PEI residues resulting from shorter heat-treatment times can also inhibit CD adsorption by covering the Pt surface and reducing the number of bare Pt sites available for CD. Therefore, despite a similar proportion of positively charged Pt species in Pt/PEI-SiO2-2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-3, the former showed lower enantioselectivity. A similar trend was observed between Pt/PEI-SiO2-1 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-5. These observations suggest that both the electronic state of the Pt species and the availability of bare Pt sites on the NP surface should be considered simultaneously in the design and preparation of Pt catalysts modified by organic molecules. 3.3 Versatility and reusability of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst for the enantioselective hydrogenation For the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst with the highest performance in the enantioselective MP hydrogenation, its versatility was investigated using different chiral modifiers, H2 pressures, or substrates. First, in addition to CD, other cinchona alkaloids, including CN, QD, and QN were used in MP hydrogenation and the enantioselectivities of the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalysts were compared (Table 5 ). Notably, CD (QN) and CN (QD), which exhibit diastereomeric relationships, produced the (R)- and (S)-enantiomers, respectively, as the main chiral products. Regardless of the chiral modifier, Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 achieved a higher ee than Pt/SiO2, demonstrating the enhanced enantioselectivity resulting from the modification of the SiO2 support with PEI and further confirming the versatility of the prepared Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst. In the enantioselective MP hydrogenation using CD as a chiral modifier, the ee values of the Pt/SiO2 and Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalysts were further compared at various H2 pressures between 0.1–5.0 MPa. As shown in Fig. 6 , the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst exhibited a higher enantioselectivity than Pt/SiO2 at all H2 pressures, confirming its superiority even under different operating conditions. Up to a H2 pressure of 1.0 MPa, the enantioselectivities of both catalysts increased with an increasing H2 pressure, reaching a maximum of 87.0% ee for Pt/SiO2 and 96.1% ee for Pt/PEI-SiO2-3. A further increase in the H2 pressure caused the enantioselectivity of Pt/SiO2 to decrease, giving a value of 83.1% ee at 5.0 MPa. This reduction appeared to be due to hydrogenation of the quinoline moiety of the chiral modifier at high H2 pressures, leading to unstable adsorption of the chiral modifier on the Pt surface [53–55]. However, Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 retained a high enantioselectivity (i.e., 96.1% ee) at 5.0 MPa, confirming that stable modification of the Pt NPs was achieved by the PEI residues, even at elevated H2 pressures. The enhanced enantioselectivity and versatility of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst was further demonstrated in the hydrogenation of several substrates, including EP, MBF, and EOPB (Table 6 ). Depending on the substrate, the ee values achieved at full conversion decreased in the following order: MP > EP > EOPB > MBF. Importantly, the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst exhibited an ∼9–14% higher ee than Pt/SiO2 regardless of the substrate, confirming the improved performance of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 in the enantioselective hydrogenation of all substrates. To evaluate the reusability of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst, ten consecutive catalytic cycles of MP hydrogenation were performed at both 0.1 MPa H2 and 1.0 MPa H2 (Fig. 7 ). After each cycle, the used catalyst was separated from the product via centrifugation and washed three times with the solvent (AcOH). Some loss of catalyst was inevitable during the repeated separation steps. Therefore, to measure the enantioselectivity at full conversion, a 3.3-fold higher catalyst loading (100 mg) was used to ensure 100% conversion in the final cycle. The subsequent cycle was performed using the recovered catalyst, fresh substrate, fresh chiral modifier, and fresh solvent under identical conditions. It is noteworthy that under full conversion conditions at 0.1 MPa H2, high enantioselectivity was maintained throughout the catalytic cycles, with an ee of 90.5% even after the last cycle, indicating a minimal loss of less than 1% compared to the first cycle (90.9% ee). To further assess the stability of the catalyst system under a different regime, we conducted a reusability test under controlled low-conversion conditions across ten consecutive reactions (Fig. S8). The results showed consistent values for both conversion and ee, confirming the catalyst’s robustness under both high- and low-conversion conditions. Furthermore, even at an elevated H2 pressure of 1.0 MPa, the highest ee of 96.1% was maintained over 10 consecutive cycles, thereby highlighting the potential of the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst for use as a reusable and enantioselective heterogeneous catalyst. Following these reusability tests, the spent catalyst was further characterized to investigate the stabilities of the PEI residues and Pt NPs on the Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst. As observed for the fresh Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst, the presence of PEI residues on the catalyst surface was confirmed by FTIR spectroscopy, with peaks being observed at 2850, 2935, and 1385 cm−1 (Fig. 8 ). In addition, the XPS spectra of the spent catalyst revealed that positively charged Pt species remained relatively abundant even after consecutive reactions, indicating that the electron-deficient state of the Pt surface was retained under reaction conditions (Fig. S9). These results, together with the high enantioselectivity maintained throughout successive reaction cycles, demonstrate the high stability of the PEI residues. The Pt NPs in the spent Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst remained stable, with only minimal Pt leaching observed during cycling (Table S2). Moreover, the TEM image of the spent catalyst shows the presence of well-dispersed Pt NPs with an average size of 1.7 nm, which is consistent with that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. 9 ). The observation of no peaks corresponding to Pt crystallites also confirmed that there was no aggregation of Pt NPs (Fig. S10). Furthermore, the EDS mapping images of the spent Pt/PEI-SiO2-3 catalyst that Pt, C and N remain homogeneously dispersed (Fig. S11), emphasizing the excellent catalyst stability, and demonstrating the potential of this support modification strategy for designing highly enantioselective and stable heterogeneous catalysts. 4 Conclusions In this study, SiO2 supports were modified with the N-rich polymer PEI to design highly enantioselective Pt catalysts for the hydrogenation of α-keto esters. To investigate the role of PEI and its beneficial effects on the enantioselectivity, the heat-treatment time was varied to control the amount of the PEI on the SiO2 support. The PEI-derived organic residues generated after heat-treatment strongly interacted with the Pt NPs in the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts, partially covering the active Pt surface sites and modulating the electronic states of the NPs. More specifically, electron transfer from the Pt surface to the PEI residues resulted in the formation of more positively charged Pt species. Notably, all Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts demonstrated superior enantioselectivities compared to the unmodified Pt/SiO2 catalyst in the enantioselective MP hydrogenation at a H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa, thereby demonstrating the promoting effect of the PEI residues. Furthermore, the optimized Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalyst consistently outperformed the Pt/SiO2 catalyst over a wide range of reactants, chiral modifiers, and H2 pressures, achieving the highest enantioselectivity of 96.1%. Moreover, the enhanced enantioselectivity was maintained over ten consecutive cycles, even at a higher H2 pressure of 1.0 MPa, confirming the stability of the modified catalyst. Notably, the positive correlation between the proportion of positively charged Pt species and the enantioselectivity suggests that the excellent enantioselectivities obtained with the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts are due to the enhanced adsorption of chiral modifiers via the quinoline moiety on the electron-deficient Pt surface. This work provides insight into organic-inorganic interactions in heterogeneous catalysts using support materials modified with organic molecules, and into the strategy for improving enantioselectivity by fine-tuning the electronic states of the active NPs. coredata.dc:description: The design of highly enantioselective heterogeneous catalysts offers an efficient route for the production of enantiopure chiral molecules, which are crucial intermediates in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and fine chemical industries. In this study, we present a strategy to enhance the enantioselectivity of supported Pt catalysts for the hydrogenation of α-keto esters by modifying SiO2 supports with poly(ethyleneimine) (PEI), a nitrogen-rich polymer. By adjusting the heat-treatment time, the quantity of PEI-derived residues on the support was successfully controlled, thereby fine-tuning the electronic state of Pt through electron-transfer interactions, and resulting in the generation of positively charged Pt species. Catalytic evaluations showed that the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts exhibited superior enantioselectivities compared to the unmodified Pt/SiO2, with an optimal performance of 96.1% enantiomeric excess (ee). In addition, the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalysts exhibited high enantioselectivities using various α-keto esters, chiral modifiers, and H2 pressures, as well as an excellent reusability over ten consecutive cycles. The observed correlation between the higher proportion of positively charged Pt species and the increased ee suggests that the improved enantioselectivity of the Pt/PEI-SiO2 catalyst system is driven by the enhanced adsorption of chiral modifiers, which is facilitated by interactions between the anchoring moiety and the electron-deficient Pt surface. These findings highlight the essential role of interactions between the active metals and the modifying organic species bound to support materials in enhancing the enantioselectivity. Moreover, they provide valuable insights for catalyst design through electronic tuning of the active metal surface with organic-modified supports.
